data.text: @starwars Rian had his chance, was paid to do a job. Now it’s time for him to fade away, and let fans build up their excitement and anticipation for Episode IX. After all, Star Wars is at its core a story of Hope.

@starwars There will be many revisitations made to the long list of fan complaints about The Last Jedi, which will grow louder now that principle filming had begun for Episode IX. It would be preferable that Rian not respond, as it takes the spotlight off the new movie. >

@starwars I am very excited to see where @jjabrams takes us with his story, and would prefer to simply put The Last Jedi behind us. Speculation and theorizing what might happen is part of the excitement and build up for the movie, & JJ does a great job of playing that game. >

@starwars Rian doesn’t have to come forward & accept the blame for the issues fans have with The Last Jedi. Nor does he have to acknowledge his movie had any flaws at all. He created the film he wanted to make. But it is not OK for him to lash out at fans who voice an opinion.

@starwars The remaining blame goes to Rian, whether he likes it or not. His inability to take a step back and view his film with a critical eye is Rian’s biggest failing. Then to attack a long time Star Wars devotee adds insult to injury.

@starwars Some of this failing belongs to @DisneyStudios, who allowed The Last Jedi to go the audience when clearly there were problems. At some point executives saw the movie. Deadlines or not, the movie needed re-editing. >

@starwars This was what Rian created and provided to Star Wars fans, who were excited to finally see Luke Skywalker back on the screen. Fans wanted to once again sink into the mystic world of the Dark & Light sides of the Force, and were left wanting. This was a failing.

@starwars Where The Force Awakens had a dashing Kylo Ren, Rian had him greasy and unkempt. And in the moment where Rey was confronting the Dark Side, where any number of secrets & truths could have been addressed, we were given awkward, empty finger snapping. >

@starwars My dislike of the movie had nothing to do with the cast, or anyone’s portrayal of a character. It was the amount of time wasted on tangential scenes, with lesser characters taking screen time away from the actual story. The movie was disjointed, & didn’t flow. >
